    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Amendment [29th June, 1984] to Question [29th June, 1984],

    "That this House, having noted the Report of the Committee on the Problems of the Aged - A Blue Paper by the Ministry of Health, February 1984, as contained in Paper Misc. 3 of 1984, approves the

Column: 1626

recommendations of the Committee on the Problems of the Aged." - [Minister for Health].

    Which Amendment was,

    To leave out "approves the recommendations of the Committee on the Problems of the Aged" appearing in lines 3 and 4 and insert -

    "recommends to the Government to adopt the Report, after making appropriate amendments to the recommendations taking into consideration the views expressed by this House". - [Mr Lim Boon Heng].

Column: 1627



     Mr Speaker: Notice of an amendment* to the amendment from the Member for Anson is set out in the Order Paper. This proposed amendment to the amendment is similar in effect to, and supersedes, the amendment to the Original Question of which the Member for Anson had previously given notice.
*The amendment, standing in the name of Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam, reads as follows:

    'As an amendment to the amendment, "To leave out the words 'recommends to the Government to adopt the Report, after making appropriate amendments to the recommendations taking into consideration the views expressed by this House' proposed to be inserted, and there to insert-

    'calls upon the government to reject the proposal of the Committee that the government should consider raising the age for withdrawal of CPF savings at first to 60 and later to 65'.".


    I shall propose again the question on the amendment of the Member for Kebun Baru.

    The Question is, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

    Following the agreement of the House, debate will range over the Original Question, the amendment of the Member for Kebun Baru, and the proposed amendment to the amendment of the Member for Anson.
2.33 pm

     The Minister of State for Culture (Maj Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, we have heard many comments by hon. Members on the Report of the Committee on the Problems of the Aged. There have been more brickbats than bouquets, I am afraid. Speeches ranged over the sociological, economic, as well as the cultural aspects. Unfortunately, only a few Members here managed to touch on the political aspect of the Report. I must say, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the Report as a whole is praiseworthy. This is the first time Singaporeans have spent time to look into the problems of the elder citizens.

    In going through the Report, Sir, I also looked at the bibliography of references. I was impressed by the literature taken from the various countries which included - of course, 11 of them were from Singapore-Australia, Britain, United States, France, Japan and even Korea, what the United Nations has termed as a NIC - newly industrialized countries.

Column: 1628



    We have done well, Sir, for the last 25 years. The PAP has succeeded on two basic beliefs. One is that we have not created a special class citizen. There were good things to be given out - housing, social welfare aid, licences. We have not given out all these goodies by virtue of the fact that so-and-so is a member of the Party - the PAP. We have not done that and yet we have succeeded. We have ruled with firmness and fairness. We have not created a special class citizen.

    The second, Mr Speaker, Sir, is our ability to anticipate problems, not problems of the day but problems of the future. This is a plus - point for the PAP. But, unfortunately, we may be guilty of carrying out what we call "the anticipation of the problems" far too long and far too much weight has been given to this. Of course, it is easy for us not to do anything now and leave it to, what the Second Minister for Health would call, the third generation leadership. That is the easiest way out. But that will be an irresponsible act.

    Looking through the Report, I was impressed because one of these days inevitably, that is, if we live that long, we will find ourselves as members of that community. The difference is that we would then be on the receiving end. That is the difference.

    I must commend the Minister for a job well done, all except one, that is. Popularly dubbed as the Howe Report, if I may also imitate the Minister's style of holding the Report in one hand, with one finger of the other pointing to Providence - I am afraid, Sir, the Report part of it is as controversial as Howe was a highly misunderstood man. I know the Minister, Sir. In fact, I enjoy sparring with him, a gentleman true to heart, a very sincere, tough-speaking but soft-hearted man.

Column: 1629



    In fact, Sir, I did send to the Minister a couple of literature on the subject when the Committee was meeting. For the first one, I earned high praise from him for my concern. But I dared not accept those kind words because that would put me in high danger, because he compared me with somebody who is real high. The second one, Sir, I sent him an article on the demographical influence on the economy - an article on the US situation, that the economy is now feeling the effects of the baby boom years. Throw us back 25 years in 1959, the 5Os and early 60s, there were really baby booms and they all now have come of age.

    The result is that many new industries emerged. So we have got the T-shirt generation, and the hamburger generation. But many industries which depended on producing consumer goods for the elder generation declined. Some even folded up. What will happen when the present T-shirt generation and the hamburger generation reach their middle age and the old age? The economy and the industry will have to be revamped to cater for them. In fact, the demographic changes in the population are a very serious matter. Unfortunately, people can hardly appreciate the significance.

    When the PAP came to power in 1959, faced with a nearly empty coffer (I remember it was $10 million in the red after selling Christmas Island) we were then concerned with the most grievous problem of finding jobs for the younger people. At that time, more than 50% of our population were below the age of 21. Our Cabinet then was the youngest in the world. We had no time for problems of the elders then. We were looking for jobs. We were trying to provide housing, a shelter for the people. And now we can afford to spend time on the elders. We have come a long way, a good way, although a hard way. We are now more secure, with full employment, better standard of living, better homes, better in everything. Of course, if the Member for Anson asks what have we got in the last 25 years, I invite him to look at himself. He is the proof. So in that situation, it is only right that we

Column: 1630

should look into problems that will affect the country some time later.

    But let us not carry this too far. I am afraid to say, Sir, that the Government has a habit of trying to find immediate solutions to problems that will come 20, 30, 40 years from now. Far-sightedness is a good thing, Sir, but short-sightedness in politics is going to be disastrous, as the Member for Serangoon Gardens warned yesterday. I commend the Minister for his far-sightedness but I do question his short-sightedness in his political approach.

    I remember something very similar to an article I sent to the Minister about the projection of the population in the years 2010, 2020 and 2030 by an American writer. The Report also reflected that - the years 2010, 2020 and 2030. So it is not our problem alone. It is an American problem given a Singapore dressing. Fair enough, insofar as those portions which are relevant to us. Perhaps if I may put in a language that the Minister would understand. It is a case of a correct diagnosis but with the wrong prognosis, resulting in the wrong prescription of medicine.

    The Second Minister for Health, his colleague, once told the Member for Rochore who criticized certain aspects of the work of the Ministry (that the Member for Rochore was the former Minister for Health) that when he left the Ministry, he left his glasses behind. I think the Minister for Health and the Second Minister for Health are looking at the problem with two pairs of tinted glasses. They do not need glasses. They need a political periscope.

    At the rate we go and if the Report were to be accepted in toto, at best, Mr Speaker, Sir, it will give out the wrong signal that the Government is being over-protective. There is nothing wrong in being over-protective. But let us work within the confines of reason. At worst, Mr Speaker, Sir, it may create a wrong reading by the people that the Government's management philosophy is based on complete distrust of the people. When I stand on a stage to deliver political speeches, I was governed by one basic objective. In my mind, in my heart, I thought to myself, "Look, fellows, please listen to me, because if you do not, I am in trouble. "The

Column: 1631

new philosophy, Sir, is this: "Look, you fellows, you bloody hell listen to me, because if you do not, you are in trouble." That is the new philosophy. We have to rally people to our side and to harness their energy and their views towards a common objective.

    The Howe report is a good report, only to be washed out by one single proposal, that of withholding the CPF money at the age of 55. Mr Speaker, Sir, someone has said that our success is a miracle. We do have miracle solutions, miracle cures, Sir. The CPF happens to be a miracle cure for many social ills. Every time we get into trouble, look at the CPF. The Minister argued passionately in this House that the CPF is for pension, for old age security. Indeed, he argued with equal passion, more vigorous, of course, without the benefit of your Chairmanship, Sir - the discussion the Minister had with us was really more vigorous and certainly less decorous. Our views were not convincing, neither were his. He argued passionately that the CPF is for old age pension. I only hope the Minister can get his Cabinet colleagues to agree with him because I think his Cabinet colleagues think otherwise. The CPF is for everything. If you want to salvage the SBS, you think of the CPF and allow them to buy shares. Is that for old age pension? Is the Minister brave enough today to revoke those monies spent to buy SBS shares? One cannot have it both ways. When you want to do something, the CPF can be used to buy shares. Now, for old age security, "We hold it back for you."

    I only support two schemes for using the CPF. From my stint in the Ministry of Labour, my own belief and my understanding of the CPF, I only support two schemes. One is the housing scheme, the other is Medisave. Yet, even in the implementation of Medisave, a great misunderstanding was created. There needed to be an explanation. What is lacking, Mr Speaker, Sir, in this whole exercise is the lack of political skill in communication - how to sell a product. The Member for Toa Payoh is overseas. He should be able to advise the Minister on how to sell even an unacceptable product.

Column: 1632



    My advice to the Minister is: don't tinker with people's money. They have planned their lives. They have earned their keeps. What is there for the Government to beg-rudge them using their money for a trip overseas? For all the years of sweat and toil, what is so grievously wrong for a person who wants to visit his kinsfolk in China, or in India? What is there for us to begrudge them? What is so wrong with his going back to India to look at his 'thambis' and 'thangachis'? What is so wrong for him to go to China to look at his 'achek' and his 'apek'? What is wrong for a Muslim to take out the money at the age of 55 to go to the Tanah Suchi, the Holy Land, to fulfil one of the five pillars of Islam? We have just finished 'Puasa Bulan Ramadan', one of the pillars of Islam. The fifth is, if the Minister does not understand, it is: 'Menunaikan Fardhu haji ke Mekah'. That is the last one, the pledge to visit the Holy Land. I speak for a good number of Malay voters in my constituency. I throw a party for them every year, the seventh year now, for the bakal bakal haji, to visit the Holy Land. Do you expect a person at the age of 60 to walk around the Kaabah seven times, being pushed along by the bigger pilgrims - and what if he happens to be at the outside fringe of the Kaabah?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, when a person has lived up to that age, having worked, toiled and sweated for so many years, I say that he is entitled to spend his savings in the way that is best to satisfy his own pledge to his religion, to his kinfolk and to his conscience. Why should we begrudge these people? Of course, holding back the CPF has its advantage, but is there a need for us now to provide an immediate solution to a problem that will come in the year 2030? Those who voted for the PAP at the age of 22 in 1959, add 25 years, they are now 47, 50 perhaps. Who are these people? They are now heads of households. They influence the thinking in the family. They have their own peer group. They speak with experience, bitter, sweet experience with their working colleagues. They know what to do. Are we here to beg-rudge them, to question them? In a few years, all of us will be elders. I do speak, Mr Speaker, Sir, as the older generation politically, although age-wise I am not. Perhaps the Minister might want to listen

Column: 1633

to a person who comes from the ground, a person who belongs to the political elders, if I may "pu shi i lau mai lau". But I claim to speak with authority on that, and I do not apologize for this boast. When we rally the people behind us, we give them hope. We do not give them despair.

    Old people need more than old age homes, more than homes for the aged sick. The Member for Anson thought that by providing more homes for the aged and more homes for the aged sick, we would have solved the problem. Of course, they deserve our attention - every bit of our attention. We do not need the Member for Anson to tell us that. We started activities for the elders long before his emergence in this House. Old people need more than homes for the aged, more than homes for the aged sick. They are the minority, Mr Speaker, Sir. Fortunately, they are the minority and, of course, we will look after them. The majority of the elders need company. Loneliness can even be worse than terminal illness because it attacks his mind. We have got to provide opportunities for these old people not only to feel that they are part of the community but also to feel that they are wanted and that they can still be productive in different ways to contribute towards society. They need company. They want to see the world a little bit more. They want to eat a little bit more, maybe better food. What we say in Chinese is, "Duo chi yi dian, duo kan yi dian shi jie". And here we say, "Look, don't look at the world. You don't deserve to look at the world. We are going to keep your savings." They need that money.

    By and large, as many Members have pointed out, CPF members do not squander away their savings easily. There have been cases, Mr Speaker, Sir. I am aware of that, from my experience in the Ministry of Labour. But these cases are few and far between. We cannot just take a few cases of people squandering their money and say that the majority will have to suffer for the folly of the minority, if we believe in majority rule. There have been cases, but I do not believe people will squander their money that way.

Column: 1634



    One of the similarly commendable recommendations is the increase in tax relief from $1,000 to $2,000. It is a very attractive recommendation. But looking hard at it, I say, here is another case for a give-and-take policy. We give you the tax rebate and then we slam a tax. When the Member for Punggol raised the question of relief for parental support in the House many years ago, the then Minister for Finance (to identify him, Sir, may I mention that Dr Goh Keng Swee was then the Minister for Finance) promptly and roundly gave the Member for Punggol a lecture on filial piety and why he should not be mercenary. The Member for Punggol, of course, was caught for words. But persistent as he was - he still is - and with the support of many other Members, the question was brought up again and again. Then the late Minister for Finance, Mr Hon Sui Sen, thought otherwise. No longer was asking for relief for supporting the parents considered mercenary. He agreed to give tax relief to those who support their parents. Here, we have two views now. At one stage when you asked for relief you were being mercenary. At another stage, you were being filial, so they agreed to both!

    The Minister for Health is trying to do even better: better claims for tax relief and also the income ceiling for the elder person himself should be removed. But at what cost? At the cost of withholding the CPF at the age of 55, which means that anyone on reaching the age of 55 will pay 3 1/2% tax to the Government. This is because if I can get the money out, I'd put it in the bank, and I get more interest. So you deny him a higher interest on that money. You give him tax relief, so by the time he reaches the age of 55, he starts paying tax in the form of a sum of money being held back and earning a lower interest than it should have if it is given to him. It is a kind of an indirect tax. So, let us not be too happy about this tax relief. Read the whole recommendation, in toto, and you will find that the old people are being taxed, deliberately so.

    This, Mr Speaker, Sir, is my way of looking at it. I might be pungent in my remarks, but the fact remains that if you do not take out the money at the age of 55,

Column: 1635

you will earn 6 1/2% of "tax". And even the proposition that you can take part of the money at 55 and thereafter at 60, is totally unacceptable. At the age of 40 or even 45, a man would have contributed to CPF since the age of 21. For example, he may have started work at 18, so at the age of 40, after 22 years of work, what would be his savings in the CPF? On lower pay, lower rate of CPF and low interest, compounded interest notwithstanding, he would have less in the CPF than he would have from the age of 41 to the age of 55, where you have a higher pay and higher CPF, and therefore a higher rate of compound interest. So you take out less, with your savings in the CPF from the age of 20 to 40, but you lock up more from the age of 41 to 55. 20 years of saving would not be more than 15 years of saving. This proposition, Mr Speaker, Sir, I think, is unacceptable.

    The Member for Chong Boon has proposed that new entrants be placed under the new scheme. I am in favour of that, but with reservation. Firstly, when a young person joins the job market, or rather a new entrant to the job market, he will take on the job with an open mind. "Yes, I take on this job. I am going to get my CPF at the age of 60 or 65. Fair enough. But you guarantee my retirement. I am not going to find myself in a quandary, that at the age of 65, I lose my job and I have no money to live; at least for the next six months when I am looking for another job." But there is a danger in this proposal. If applied universally and blindly, we might deter some women who might want to join the labour market in later years when their children have grown up to an age to be able to at least look after themselves for half a day. We should not deter these women from joining the job market. If applied without any proviso, this will work against our interests. The principle is acceptable, The new entrants to the job market will come under the new scheme but the proviso must be there to make it attractive and possible for women workers to join our production brigade.

    Finally, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I just be allowed the audacity to offer a word of advice to the Minister? This is what politics is all about, When gut feelings are impinged, objectivity is expunged. Our job

Column: 1636

is to rally the people for a good cause, for the sake of their security. No government will do things which will put itself into difficulty with the voters and become unpopular in the process. However justifiable, the policy must be explainable, and here the communicative skill will come into play. This is a good policy - that is, a good Report, and I commended the Minister. May I just repeat for his benefit that he is a tough speaking, soft-hearted man. Is a good Report like this to be washed out by a single political blunder? The result is that the good points have been forgotten and the Minister is taken to task on one count. And nobody is talking about the problems of the aged now. Everybody is talking about his savings in the CPF. The Minister's effort, I am afraid, has been washed out out of his own making. And as I said, in politics when the gut feeling is pricked, it will take a long time, a really long time, Mr Speaker, Sir, to rally the people around again so that the other good points in the Report shall rightly deserve their attention by the people.

    I do beseech the Minister, and I do appeal to this House, to reconsider the question of withholding the CPF at the age of 55 and to extend it to 60 and later to 65. Let people plan their lives. Some of us will retire, hopefully, retire in bliss and gracefully too in the process. Let these people live their lives and let us plan for the future generation. We are not forsaking our responsibility. It is our job and we do not apologize for that - to plan for the future. But let those people we have served, who have contributed to building the Singapore nation, keep what they deserve.
3.04pm

     Mr Lai Tha Chai (Henderson)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion by the Member for Kebun Baru.

    At last Friday's Parliament sitting, the Health Minister said that what we are concerned about are the aged 20 years from now. In other words, the aged of the future and not the aged of today. It will not be he, but maybe me. I am not speaking for myself just as he is not speaking for himself. But it shows that the Government

Column: 1637

is concerned that most of the aged of the future will not be able to make careful calculation in budgetting. They will be in a very difficult situation if they do not know how to make a living. By the time they get to around 60 years old, they may end up in a miserable and helpless situation. So the Government wants them to take pre-cautionary measures by planning ahead.

    The Minister said that now the medical care is very good. So when a person reaches 65 or above he will still be able to live very well and can do many things. The men will get stronger as they get older. Just like the Member for Alexandra said, they still have the last Spring. To quote the Chinese writer, Ba Jin, it is the Spring in the Autumn.

    For the women, when they reach that age, they will still be only half old and still retain much of their attractiveness. According to the Health Minister, when that time comes everyone will not have to worry about food and they do not have to worry about clothing. They will be happily enjoying their old age. This is a well intentioned plan.

    As what the Member for Kampong Chai Chee has said, this is a very good Report. I will give two instances. We have been debating whether the children will be able to get tax relief if their parents live with them. Now the Report says that they need not live with their parents. As long as they can prove that they are supporting their parents, they will get the tax relief. I think this is a very good recommendation. Not all parents would like to stay with their children and not all the children would like to live with their parents. But they are still a family.

    The second example is that the Report suggests that the tax relief for old men can be raised from the present $4,000 to $12,000 to encourage people above 60 to continue working and they do not have to pay income tax. I think this is also a good recommendation. But there is no acclaim.

    Since the release of this Report, from what I have heard and what he has heard, those who banged tables and yelled are found everywhere. But those who say

Column: 1638

something good and those who applaud, I have not come across any. All I have noted is the issue of the withdrawal of CPF. So everybody is questioning the Minister for Health. This is not without reason. In our society today, nobody talks about human relationship which is as thin as paper. People only talk about money. If you ask the old people not to withdraw their CPF savings at 55, of course they will not be happy. Sir, you are a surgeon, you know psychology. The Minister is not a surgeon. He is only a Health Minister. He has to listen to advice on human psychology.

    Secondly, we live in a tropical country. A person struggles to earn his living during the day incurs mental and physical exhaustion. As the Member for Delta has said, many of them become very weak even before they get old. This is a fact.

    More important, there is this problem of heart disease and cancer. These two are very common diseases. Because of this the people are worried about how long they are going to live. You can't ensure them long life. How do you convince them? So if we tell them that the withdrawal age of CPF will be raised, of course they will not be happy.

    Thirdly, we Asians tend to think that very few people could live to the age of 70. So when they reach 60 they would like to celebrate the birthday. The Minister for Health could also celebrate his 60th birthday. By the time they reach 60 and above, if they die out of an accident or anything, they could say that they have nothing to regret as they have already enjoyed life. As what the Member for Kolam Ayer said, they also need to withdraw the money from CPF to perform the Haj. I met a Malay constituent at one of my Meet the People's sessions. He said that there is only one thing in his mind which he would like to raise. I asked him what it was. He said, "It is very important. The CPF is the most important thing in my mind."

    Fourthly, when a person reaches 55, like what we have been talking about in Parliament these two days, there are these questions: Is that person able to work. Will he be able to get a job? Will he be secure in his work? Nobody knows and nobody can be sure. People say there are two sad

Column: 1639

things when a person reaches middle age. He finds it difficult to live on and, at the same time, he is not willing to die. Frankly, there is only a small proportion of people, about 2% belonging to the upper middle class who will be able to have a comfortable life when they get old. But the majority of the people have to toil and struggle for, a living. They will have the worries like those raised by the Health Minister. So if you worry for them, you think you are right, But they say we know better ourselves. The Health Minister seems to be concerned about the aged in 20 year's time. But whatever action you are taking you are also affecting those people who are in the 40-50s now, as you are locking up their money. This is too hasty!
